questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of kidney transplantation two years ago presents to the emergency department with fever, weight loss, and a productive cough for the past week. He is currently on immunosuppressive therapy. Physical examination shows crackles over the lung fields and a chest X-ray reveals multiple nodular infiltrates. A Gram stain of the sputum is shown below. Which of the following characteristics is most likely demonstrated by the organism causing this patient's symptoms?
A 21 years old patient Suyash came to OPD with history of fall on hand. Now he is having pain at hand region. X ray of patient is given. Which of the following joint has been shown in his X ray ?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ellipsoid joint

 

 

The X-ray depicts the radiocarpal joint, which is also known as the wrist joint. This is an ellipsoid joint (a subtype of synovial joints) formed by the articulation of the radius with the carpal bones (scaphoid, lunate, and triquetrum).

 

 

Key Features of the Radiocarpal (Wrist) Joint:

 

  1. Joint Type: Ellipsoid (also called condyloid joint, allowing movements such as flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction.
  2. Articulating Bones: The distal end of the radius and the proximal carpal bones.
  3. Function: Enables a wide range of movements at the wrist.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hinge joint: Hinge joints, such as the elbow or interphalangeal joints, allow only flexion and extension. The wrist joint permits additional movements (e.g., abduction, adduction) and is therefore not a hinge joint.

 

Option B. Ball-and-socket joint: Ball-and-socket joints, such as the hip or shoulder, allow movements in all directions, including rotation. The wrist joint does not allow free rotation and is not classified as a ball-and-socket joint.

 

Option D. Saddle joint: Saddle joints allow movements in two planes and are seen in joints like the first carpometacarpal joint (thumb). The radiocarpal joint is not a saddle joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiocarpal (wrist) joint is an ellipsoid joint that allows a variety of movements, including flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. This makes it unique from other joint types like hinge or saddle joints.

A 24-year-old female presents to your office with burning urination, urgency and frequency. She is sexually active. Urine cultures show catalase-positive, gram-positive cocci. The organism responsible for this patient's symptoms is most likely to be:

choices.text: A microorganism should be constantly associated with the lesions of the disease
It should be possible to isolate the bacterium in pure culture from the lesions
Inoculation of such pure culture into laboratory animals should reproduce the lesions
Administration of broad-spectrum antimicrobial agent dependably eradicates the organisms and cures the diseases

questions.text: All are Koch’s postulates except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Administration of broad-spectrum antimicrobial agent dependably eradicates the organisms and cures the diseases

 

  • Koch’s postulates are classical criteria used to establish the causal relationship between a microorganism and a disease.
  • They include:
    1. The microorganism is found in all cases of the disease.
    2. It can be isolated in pure culture.
    3. Inoculation of this pure culture into a susceptible host reproduces the disease.
    4. The same organism can be re-isolated from the experimentally infected host.
  • Statement D is not one of Koch’s postulates; it refers instead to a therapeutic principle (antimicrobial eradication), not proof of causation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A microorganism should be constantly associated with the lesions of the disease: This is Koch’s first postulate → establishing consistent presence of the microorganism in diseased cases.

 

Option B. It should be possible to isolate the bacterium in pure culture from the lesions: Koch’s second postulate → laboratory isolation in pure culture.

 

Option C. Inoculation of such pure culture into laboratory animals should reproduce the lesions: Koch’s third postulate → reproduction of the disease in experimental hosts.

questions.text: Match the following intracranial aneurysms with their Characteristic features:
What is the typical fiber arrangement of lumbrical muscles in the hand?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1st & 2nd lumbricals – Unipennate, 3rd & 4th lumbricals – bipennate

 

The lumbrical muscles of the hand are intrinsic muscles responsible for flexion at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extension at the interphalangeal (IP) joints. These muscles are classified based on their fiber arrangement:

 

  • 1st and 2nd lumbricals: Unipennate fibers – Their muscle fibers are arranged on only one side of the central tendon.
  • 3rd and 4th lumbricals: Bipennate fibers – Their muscle fibers are arranged on both sides of the central tendon, which increases their strength.

 

This unique arrangement allows the lumbricals to perform precise movements of the fingers.

 

Note:

 

 

Classification of Muscle Fiber Arrangement:

 

Muscle fibers can be arranged in various patterns to optimize strength, flexibility, and movement efficiency. The major types of arrangements are:

 

1. Parallel Muscle Fibers:

 

  • Fibers run parallel to the central axis.
  • Examples: Sartorius (strap-like muscle), Thyrohyoid (quadrilateral muscle).

 

2. Pinnate Muscle Fibers:

 

  • Fibers are obliquely arranged to a central tendon.
  • Subtypes:
    • Unipennate: Fibers are arranged on one side of the tendon.
      • Examples: 1st and 2nd lumbricals in the hand.
    • Bipennate: Fibers are arranged on both sides of the tendon.
      • Examples: 3rd and 4th lumbricals, Deltoid (middle fibers), Subscapularis.
    • Multipennate: Multiple tendons with fibers on each side.
      • Examples: Deltoid (overall structure), Subscapularis.

 

3. Circumpennate:

 

  • Central tendon with muscle fibers arranged circularly around it.
  • Example: Tibialis anterior.

 

4. Cruciate Muscle Fibers:

 

  • Fibers cross in a crisscross pattern.
  • Examples: Masseter, Sternocleidomastoid.

 

5. Twisted or Spiral Muscle Fibers:

 

  • Upper fibers move downward and lower fibers move upward in a spiral arrangement.
  • Examples: Latissimus dorsi, Pectoralis major.

 

Special Classifications:

 

  • Quadrilateral Muscle: Four-sided, flat muscles.
    • Example: Thyrohyoid.
  • Strap-Like Muscle: Long and thin, with parallel fibers.
    • Example: Sartorius.
  • Strap-Like Muscle with Tendinous Intersections:
    • Example: Rectus abdominis.
  • Spindle-Shaped Muscle: Tapered at both ends with a wider belly in the middle.
    • Example: Biceps brachii.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lumbrical muscles of the hand have a unipennate arrangement for the 1st and 2nd lumbricals and a bipennate arrangement for the 3rd and 4th lumbricals. This fiber arrangement is crucial for the fine motor control of the fingers.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the OPD with 3 weeks of cough, night sweats, and occasional hemoptysis. The patient also has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Sputum cultures grown on a selective medium demonstrate mycobacteria that grow in parallel chains forming serpentine cords under microscopy.  This observed growth pattern most strongly correlates with which of the following bacterial characteristics?

Fourth-year medical students are recruited for a research study assessing their ability to interpret biopsy samples obtained during routine clinical practice. As part of the study, they are given samples of normal respiratory mucosa and asked to identify the cell types present after staining with hematoxylin and eosin. The students observe that the respiratory epithelium changes in composition as the airways continue distally from the trachea to the alveolar ducts. Which of the following features is last to disappear?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cilia

 

The respiratory epithelium and supporting structures progressively change from the trachea → bronchi → bronchioles → terminal bronchioles → respiratory bronchioles → alveoli.

 

Sequence of disappearance:

 

  1. Cartilage – present in trachea and bronchi, but absent in bronchioles.
  2. Mucous glands – submucosal glands decrease and disappear in smaller bronchioles.
  3. Goblet cells – present in bronchi, decrease in terminal bronchioles, and absent beyond.
  4. Cilia – persist the longest, extending into the respiratory bronchioles (help move mucus and debris upward in the mucociliary escalator).

questions.text: Image depicted below belongs to which of the following?
All of the following muscles have dual nerve supply except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pronator teres 

 

  • Innervated by the median nerve only.
  • This is not a hybrid muscle, making it the correct answer.

 

Other options:

 

Muscles with dual nerve supply are known as hybrid muscles or composite muscles. These muscles receive innervation from two different nerves.

 

Option A. Subscapularis:

 

  • Innervated by the upper subscapular nerve and lower subscapular nerve.
  • This muscle is a hybrid muscle.

 

Option B. Pectoralis major:

 

  • Innervated by the lateral pectoral nerve and medial pectoral nerve.
  • This muscle is a hybrid muscle.

 

Option D. Flexor digitorum profundus:

 

  • Innervated by:
    • The anterior interosseous nerve (a branch of the median nerve) for the lateral half (index and middle fingers).
    • The ulnar nerve for the medial half (ring and little fingers).
    • This muscle is a hybrid muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pronator teres muscle is not a hybrid muscle, as it is supplied solely by the median nerve, while all the other muscles in the question (subscapularis, pectoralis major, flexor digitorum profundus) receive dual nerve supply.

In an experiment, a resistant HSV type 2 strain containing this mutation is cultured in a cell line, and the cell culture is coinfected with a nonresistant HSV type 1 strain. It is found that some of the newly produced type 1 virions acquire resistance to acyclovir, and subsequent progeny continue to be resistant. A 45-year-old office worker complains of persistent wrist pain and difficulty performing repetitive tasks on a computer keyboard. Physical examination reveals tenderness at the wrist joint and decreased range of motion, particularly during wrist flexion and extension. Radiographic evaluation shows evidence of degenerative changes in the joint space. Which of the following bones is not directly involved in the formation of the wrist joint ?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulna

 

The wrist joint (radiocarpal joint) is formed by the articulation between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones, specifically the scaphoid, lunate, and (partially) the triquetral. The ulna, however, is not directly involved in the wrist joint because it is separated from the carpal bones by the triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC), which serves as a cushion and stabilizer.

 

 

Key Points:

 

  • Bones directly involved in the wrist joint:
    • Radius: Forms the primary articulation with the scaphoid and lunate.
    • Scaphoid: A proximal carpal bone articulating with the radius.
    • Lunate: Another proximal carpal bone articulating with the radius.
    • Triquetral: Indirectly involved when the wrist is in ulnar deviation.
  • Bone NOT involved:
    • Ulna: The ulna does not participate in the wrist joint because of the TFCC, which separates it from the carpal bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ulna is not directly involved in the wrist joint due to the triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC), which separates it from the carpal bones. The wrist joint is primarily formed by the radius, scaphoid, lunate, and partially the triquetral bones.

choices.text: Tail of spence extends across anterior axillary fold.
Inner quadrants of breast contain the most breast tissue
The suspensory ligaments of cooper's ligaments are found in the lower part of breast.
Breast is made up of 10 lobes

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the anatomy of the breast?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tail of spence extends across anterior axillary fold

 

The Tail of Spence (axillary tail) is an extension of breast tissue that passes superolaterally across the anterior axillary fold into the axilla.
It is clinically significant because carcinoma of the breast can spread into the axilla via this tail.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inner quadrants of breast contain the most breast tissue: This is false. The upper outer quadrant contains the greatest amount of breast tissue including the tail of Spence. This is also the most common site of breast carcinoma.

 

Option C. The suspensory ligaments of Cooper’s ligaments are found in the lower part of breast: This is false. Cooper’s ligaments are fibrous bands extending throughout the breast, connecting the dermis of the skin to the pectoral fascia, not just the lower part. Their infiltration by carcinoma causes skin dimpling.

 

Option D. Breast is made up of 10 lobes: This is false. The breast typically consists of 15–20 lobes, each drained by a lactiferous duct opening at the nipple.

The symptoms developed about 2 weeks after he had unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner.  Gram stain of the discharge is shown. A sample of the discharge is placed on an antibiotic-containing medium, and bacterial colonies are cultured. Which of the following terms best describes the medium?

During examination of a patient with an intern, the professor asks the patient to invert his foot and he points at the prominent tendon behind the medial malleolus. Which is the tendon being pointed at here?
Mesencephalic nucleus of trigeminal nerve receives which of the following sensation?

A 22-year-old athlete presents with pain in the posterior aspect of his hip after a sprinting injury. On examination, the pain is localized to the ischial tuberosity. Which of the following muscles is most likely involved, given its attachment to the ischial tuberosity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biceps Femoris

 

The ischial tuberosity is the origin site for several posterior thigh muscles, particularly the hamstring muscles, which include:

 

  1. Biceps femoris (long head)
  2. Semitendinosus
  3. Semimembranosus
  4. Adductor magnus (ischial head)

 

 

In this case, pain at the ischial tuberosity following a sprinting injury strongly suggests involvement of the hamstring muscles, as these muscles originate from the ischial tuberosity and are frequently injured in activities involving sprinting or sudden acceleration.

 

Key Reason for Choosing Biceps Femoris:

 

  • Among the hamstring muscles, biceps femoris is often affected in sprinting injuries due to its role in knee flexion and hip extension.
  • Although the adductor magnus (ischial head). also originates from the ischial tuberosity, its primary function is hip adduction and extension, which is less involved in sprinting mechanics compared to the biceps femoris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluteus Maximus: The gluteus maximus inserts into the iliotibial tract and gluteal tuberosity of the femur, not the ischial tuberosity. It is involved in hip extension but does not originate from the ischial tuberosity.

 

Option C. Adductor Magnus: The ischial head of the adductor magnus does originate from the ischial tuberosity, but this muscle is less likely to be injured during sprinting compared to the hamstrings.

 

Option D. Iliopsoas: The iliopsoas inserts into the lesser trochanter of the femur and is primarily a hip flexor. It does not originate from the ischial tuberosity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ischial tuberosity serves as the origin for the hamstring muscles, including the biceps femoris, which is commonly injured in sprinting-related activities due to its role in knee flexion and hip extension. Among the options, biceps femoris is the most likely muscle involved in this injury.

choices.text: Loss of taste sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue
Loss of taste sensation from posterior 1/3 tongue
Loss of general sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue
Loss of taste sensation from posterior most part of tongue

questions.text: Injury to the nerve that lies medially to the structure pointed will result in?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of taste sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue

 

The nerve medially related to the jugular foramen is the chorda tympani nerve, a branch of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), which carries taste sensation from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue.

 

 

Key Points:

 

  1. Chorda Tympani Nerve:
    • The chorda tympani carries taste fibers from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue and joins the lingual nerve to provide this sensation.
    • The chorda tympani nerve courses medially relative to the jugular foramen.
  2. Injury to this nerve results in the loss of taste sensation from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Loss of taste sensation from posterior 1/3 tongue: This is incorrect because the posterior 1/3 of the tongue's taste sensation is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX).

 

Option C. Loss of general sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue: This is incorrect because general sensation of the anterior 2/3 of the tongue is supplied by the lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3).

 

Option D. Loss of taste sensation from posterior most part of tongue: This is incorrect because the posterior-most part of the tongue is innervated by the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The chorda tympani nerve is responsible for taste sensation from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue. Injury to the nerve medially related to the structure in the image results in the loss of taste sensation from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue, making A the correct answer.

An elderly female with a central line undergoes surgery. On postoperative day 3, she develops fever and tachycardia. A culture from the tip of the central line revealed brown buff colonies. Microscopy showed gram-positive organisms that reproduce by budding. What is the likely causative organism?
Identify the epithelium:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Keratinized stratified squamous epithelium

 

The provided image shows keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, commonly found in the skin (epidermis). Showing a keratinized dead layer, stratification, and squamous cell shape.

 

Key Features in the Image:

 

  1. Multiple layers of cells:
    • Indicates a stratified epithelium.
  2. Flattened nuclei in the upper layers:
    • Suggests squamous cells in the superficial layer.
  3. Pink-stained layer without nuclei at the top:
    • The absence of nuclei in the topmost layer signifies keratinization. Keratinized layers consist of dead cells filled with keratin, providing extra protection.
  4. Pigmentation (melanin):
    • Presence of pigmentation in the lower layers suggests this tissue is from the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-keratinized stratified cuboidal epithelium: Stratified cuboidal epithelium is found in sweat glands or ducts but is not seen in keratinized layers.

 

Option B. Keratinized stratified cuboidal epithelium: Cuboidal epithelium is not represented in this image as the uppermost cells are squamous.

 

Option C. Non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium: Non-keratinized epithelium has nuclei in the topmost layer and lacks the keratinized dead cell layer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The keratinized stratified squamous epithelium is a defining feature of the skin's epidermis, offering protection against mechanical stress, dehydration, and microbial invasion.

choices.text: Sensation in anterior scalp and dorsum of nose

questions.text: Sensation of which of the following structures are affected if a tumor or lesion compresses the structures passing through this opening of the skull marked A?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sensation in anterior scalp and dorsum of nose

 

The opening marked "A" in the image is the superior orbital fissure, which transmits structures including the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (V1). If a tumor or lesion compresses the structures passing through the superior orbital fissure, the sensation in the anterior scalp and dorsum of nose (Option C. is affected, as these areas are supplied by branches of V1 (ophthalmic nerve).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensation of nasopharynx: Supplied mainly by glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), not by divisions passing through the superior orbital fissure. Lesions here would affect swallowing and gag reflex, not facial sensation.

 

Option B. Mucosa of nasal cavity: Innervated by branches of the maxillary nerve (V2) through the sphenopalatine foramen. V2 passes via the foramen rotundum, not the superior orbital fissure.

 

Option D. Sensation of chin: Provided by the mental nerve, a branch of the mandibular division (V3) of trigeminal nerve. V3 exits through the foramen ovale, not the superior orbital fissure.

questions.text: In given radiological anatomy image identify the thalamus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

  1. The thalamus is a large, egg-shaped structure located in the central region of the brain.
  2. It serves as a major relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex.
  3. In the sagittal section provided, C corresponds to the thalamus.

 

Identification of the Other Labels:

 

  • A: Corpus callosum (superior to the thalamus, connecting the two cerebral hemispheres).
  • B: Fornix (a white matter tract involved in the limbic system, beneath the corpus callosum).
  • D: Hypothalamus (inferior and anterior to the thalamus, involved in homeostasis and autonomic control).
  • E: Pituitary gland (connected to the hypothalamus via the infundibulum, responsible for hormone regulation).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In radiological anatomy, the thalamus is identified as the large, centrally located structure, marked as C in this image.

questions.text: A farmer presenting with fever off and on for the past 4 years was diagnosed to be suffering from chronic brucellosis. All of the following serological tests would be helpful in the diagnosis at this state except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Standard Agglutination test

 

  • In chronic brucellosis, the antibody profile shifts:
    • Early disease → mainly IgM antibodies, detected by Standard Agglutination Test (SAT).
    • Chronic disease → mainly IgG antibodies, which do not agglutinate well in SAT.
  • Therefore, SAT is not reliable in chronic cases.
  • Tests that detect IgG antibodies (such as Coomb’s test, 2-Mercaptoethanol test, and Complement Fixation Test) are more useful in chronic disease.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. 2-Mercaptoethanol (2-ME) Test:

 

  • 2-ME destroys IgM antibodies but leaves IgG antibodies intact.
  • Since chronic brucellosis is characterized by IgG predominance, this test helps identify persistent infection by measuring IgG levels.
  • Useful to differentiate acute (IgM) vs chronic (IgG) infection.

 

Option C. Complement Fixation Test (CFT):

 

  • Detects mainly IgG antibodies (fix complement effectively).
  • In chronic brucellosis, when IgM has declined, CFT remains positive because of IgG.
  • Often used to monitor treatment response and disease progression.

 

Option D. Coombs (Antiglobulin) Test:

 

  • Detects non-agglutinating IgG antibodies that standard agglutination tests may miss.
  • Very useful in chronic or relapsed brucellosis, when SAT can be falsely negative because IgG does not agglutinate well.
  • Helps confirm longstanding disease.

questions.solution: Ans. D) Level 6: Hyoid to suprasternal notch

questions.text: Most lateral nucleus of cerebellum?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dentate

 

The cerebellum contains four deep nuclei arranged medially to laterally as follows:

 

  1. Fastigial (most medial)
  2. Globose
  3. Emboliform
  4. Dentate (most lateral and the largest).

 

 

The dentate nucleus is characterized by its tooth-like appearance (hence the name "dentate," derived from Latin for "tooth"). It is the most lateral of the cerebellar nuclei and plays a significant role in motor coordination and fine motor skills. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dentate nucleus is the most lateral and largest nucleus of the cerebellum and is essential for motor coordination.

questions.text: What is the outer covering of the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amnion

 

The condition shown in the image is omphalocele. In omphalocele, the herniated abdominal contents are covered by a sac composed of amnion on the outside and peritoneum on the inside.

 

Omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect in which the intestines and sometimes other abdominal organs herniate into the base of the umbilical cord. These herniated contents are enclosed in a sac, with the sac's outermost layer formed by the amnion and its innermost layer by peritoneum. This distinguishing feature helps differentiate omphalocele from gastroschisis, where there is no covering sac over the herniated organs

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoderm: The endoderm is the innermost germ layer formed during embryogenesis. It gives rise to the epithelial lining of the gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts, as well as organs like the liver and pancreas. It does not contribute to the outer covering of omphalocele, which is made of amnion.

 

Option B. Ectoderm: Ectoderm forms the outermost layer of the embryo and differentiates into structures such as the skin, hair, nails, and nervous system. It is responsible for creating the body's external surfaces, but not the sac around the omphalocele. The covering of omphalocele is derived from fetal membranes, not ectoderm.

 

Option C. Chorion: The chorion is an extraembryonic membrane formed from trophoblast and mesoderm, and is a component of the placenta. It surrounds the embryo and contributes to nutrient and gas exchange but does not make up the sac covering omphalocele contents. The omphalocele sac specifically has an amniotic outer layer and peritoneal inner layer.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to a PHC due to pain with intercourse and dysuria for the last 3 days. She also has had low-grade fevers and a mild headache. questions.text: Which type of gland is depicted here?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Holocrine glands 

 

The image depicts a holocrine gland, which is a type of exocrine gland where the entire cell disintegrates to release its secretory product. These glands are primarily associated with sebaceous (oil) glands in the skin. The following features are characteristic of holocrine glands:

 

  1. Cell rupture: The cells accumulate their secretions and then undergo disintegration, releasing their contents.
  2. Sebaceous glands: These glands are typically located in the skin and associated with hair follicles, as seen in the image.
  3. Histological appearance: The image shows clusters of cells with clear vacuoles containing lipid material, characteristic of sebaceous glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apocrine glands: These glands release their secretions by budding off the apical portion of the cell, commonly seen in specialized sweat glands. They are not shown in the image.

 

Option B. Merocrine glands: Merocrine glands (e.g., eccrine sweat glands) release their secretions via exocytosis without damaging the cell. The gland depicted does not have this appearance.

 

Option D. Endocrine glands: Endocrine glands release hormones directly into the bloodstream and lack ducts, unlike the gland shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gland shown in the image is a holocrine gland, specifically a sebaceous gland, characterized by the disintegration of cells to release oily secretions.

A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. All of the following organisms can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, except:
Your patient has lost the ability to discriminate between two points presented simultaneously to the skin. Your neurological evaluation is most likely to reveal a lesion in the
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medial lemniscus

 

The medial lemniscus is part of the dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway, which is responsible for transmitting fine touch, proprioception, and two-point discrimination. This pathway begins with input from the fasciculus gracilis (lower limb). and fasciculus cuneatus (upper limb), which transmit sensory information to the medulla. From there, fibers decussate and ascend as the medial lemniscus to the thalamus and ultimately the sensory cortex.

 

A lesion in the medial lemniscus disrupts these sensory modalities, leading to deficits like the inability to perform two-point discrimination, a hallmark of dorsal column dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral lemniscus:The lateral lemniscus is part of the auditory pathway and plays no role in tactile sensation or two-point discrimination.

 

Option C. Spinal lemniscus: The spinal lemniscus transmits pain, temperature, and crude touch via the lateral and anterior spinothalamic tracts. It does not transmit fine touch or proprioception.

 

Option D. Trigeminal lemniscus: The trigeminal lemniscus is associated with sensory pathways for the face and is not responsible for two-point discrimination on the skin of the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The medial lemniscus is part of the dorsal column pathway, responsible for fine touch, proprioception, and two-point discrimination. Damage to this structure results in the loss of two-point discrimination ability.

questions.text: A patient has suffered a stroke caused by occlusion of the right anterior cerebral artery. This patient is most likely to present with
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A loss of pain and temperature sensations in the left leg

 

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA). supplies the medial surface of the brain, including the areas of the primary motor and sensory cortices responsible for the lower limb. An occlusion of the right ACA affects the contralateral side (in this case, the left leg) due to the decussation of motor and sensory pathways.

 

  • The loss of pain and temperature sensations results from disruption of the sensory pathways supplying the contralateral lower limb.
  • Additionally, motor deficits such as weakness or paralysis of the contralateral lower limb can occur, but this is not the best fit based on the options provided.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Weakness of the right leg: This is incorrect because the right ACA supplies the medial surface of the right hemisphere, which corresponds to sensory and motor control of the left leg, not the right.

 

Option C. Drooping of the corner of the mouth on the left: Drooping of the corner of the mouth indicates a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve or a lesion affecting the corticobulbar tracts. The ACA does not supply the areas responsible for facial movements; these are typically affected by middle cerebral artery (MCA) strokes.

 

Option D. A nonfluent aphasia: Nonfluent aphasia (Broca’s aphasia. occurs due to lesions in the left frontal lobe (Broca's area), which is supplied by the left MCA, not the ACA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery causes deficits in the contralateral lower limb due to its supply to the medial surface of the brain, which includes motor and sensory areas associated with the lower extremities. In this case, the loss of pain and temperature sensations in the left leg is the most likely clinical manifestation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with sudden-onset facial weakness and drooping on one side of the face. The patient also complains of drooling while eating, likely due to weakness in a muscle. Which of the following structures does not pierce the involved muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Buccal branch of facial nerve

 

The muscle involved in this case is the buccinator, which is affected in facial nerve palsy. Buccinator weakness causes drooling and food accumulation in the vestibule of the mouth.

 

The buccal branch of the facial nerve, however, does not pierce the buccinator. Instead, it supplies the buccinator from its superficial surface and lies outside the muscle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Buccal branch of mandibular nerve: Sensory nerve from the anterior division of V3. It pierces the buccinator to supply mucosa and skin of the cheek.

 

Option C. Parotid duct: Traverses across the masseter, turns medially, and pierces the buccinator to open opposite the second upper molar tooth.

 

Option D. Molar mucous glands: Their ducts also pierce the buccinator muscle to open into the vestibule of the oral cavity.

A tumor of the uncinate process of the pancreas affects which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superior mesenteric artery

 

The uncinate process of the pancreas is the portion of the pancreas that projects posteriorly and lies behind the superior mesenteric vessels. A tumor in this region is likely to compress or involve the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and its accompanying vein because these structures are closely related anatomically.

 

 

  • The superior mesenteric artery and vein pass anterior to the uncinate process of the pancreas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Portal vein: The portal vein forms posterior to the neck of the pancreas, not at the uncinate process. Hence, it is not the vessel primarily affected.

 

Option C. Common hepatic artery: This artery is a branch of the celiac trunk and is not closely related to the uncinate process of the pancreas.

 

Option D. Inferior mesenteric artery: This artery arises from the abdominal aorta below the superior mesenteric artery and is unrelated to the pancreas or its uncinate process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A tumor in the uncinate process of the pancreas primarily affects the superior mesenteric artery and vein due to their close anatomical relationship.

questions.text: Superior gluteal nerve supplies all except?

A 2-week-old boy is brought to the OPD due to runny nose, low-grade fever, and skin rash for 2 days. The patient was born at 38 weeks gestation to a 19-year-old woman who had poor access to prenatal care. Temperature is 38° C (100.4° F). Vital signs are otherwise normal for age. On examination, the patient has nasal drainage and peeling skin on his face, hands, and feet. Hepatosplenomegaly and generalized lymphadenopathy are present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syphilis

 

  • A 2-week-old newborn with:
    • Runny nose (called snuffles in congenital syphilis).
    • Peeling skin on face, hands, and feet.
    • Hepatosplenomegaly + generalized lymphadenopathy.
  • These are classic signs of early congenital syphilis, usually presenting within the first 2 months of life.
  • Caused by transplacental transmission of Treponema pallidum.
  • Other possible features: rash (esp. palms and soles), osteochondritis, anemia, failure to thrive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythema multiforme:

 

  • Hypersensitivity reaction (often due to HSV, Mycoplasma).
  • Presents with target lesions on skin, not peeling skin + hepatosplenomegaly.

 

Option B. Kawasaki disease:

 

  • Vasculitis in children, usually <5 years.
  • Presents with ≥5 days fever, mucosal changes (strawberry tongue), conjunctivitis, rash, cervical lymphadenopathy.
  • Not typical in a 2-week-old infant.

 

Option C. Measles:

 

  • Presents with high fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, and then maculopapular rash.
  • Not associated with peeling skin in a neonate, and too young (maternal antibodies usually protect for first 6 months).

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer came with fever, calf tenderness, conjunctival suffusion, retro orbital pain. On examination, he has severe calf tenderness. Lab investigations show hypokalaemia and neutropenia. What is the diagnosis?
GSE fibres are present in cranial nerves:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) III, IV, VI, XII

 

General Somatic Efferent (GSE) fibers are motor fibers that supply the skeletal muscles derived from somites. These fibers are involved in voluntary motor control. The cranial nerves that contain GSE fibers and their respective muscles include:

 

  • Cranial Nerve III (Oculomotor nerve): Innervates most of the extraocular muscles, including the superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique, as well as the levator palpebrae superioris.
  • Cranial Nerve IV (Trochlear nerve): Supplies the superior oblique muscle of the eye.
  • Cranial Nerve VI (Abducens nerve): Innervates the lateral rectus muscle of the eye.
  • Cranial Nerve XII (Hypoglossal nerve): Supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue.

 

These cranial nerves have motor nuclei that are classified as GSE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GSE fibers are found in cranial nerves III (Oculomotor), IV (Trochlear), VI (Abducens), and XII (Hypoglossal), as they control skeletal muscles derived from somites.

Which of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery?

 

  1. Superior gluteal artery
  2. Inferior gluteal artery
  3. Superior vesical artery
  4. Middle rectal artery
  5. Inferior vesical artery
  6. Vaginal artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

 

The internal iliac artery is divided into anterior and posterior divisions. The anterior division primarily supplies the pelvic organs, perineum, and parts of the lower limb, while the posterior division supplies the gluteal and spinal regions.

 

Branches of the Anterior Division of the Internal Iliac Artery:

 

  1. Inferior gluteal artery (2): Supplies the gluteal region, exiting the pelvis below the piriformis.
  2. Superior vesical artery (3): Supplies the bladder.
  3. Middle rectal artery (4): Supplies the rectum.
  4. Inferior vesical artery (5) (in males) or vaginal artery (6) (in females): Supplies the bladder and nearby structures (e.g., prostate in males or vagina in females).

 

Note: 

 

Branches of the Posterior Division:

 

Mnemonic: I Love Sunny

 

  1. I: Iliolumbar artery
  2. L: Lateral sacral artery
  3. S: Superior gluteal artery

 

The superior gluteal artery (1) is the largest branch of the posterior division and exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior division of the internal iliac artery supplies the pelvic cavity (bladder, rectum, vagina, prostate) and includes branches such as the inferior gluteal, superior vesical, middle rectal, inferior vesical, and vaginal arteries.

A 44 yr old female presents to the OPD with high grade fever, pain that is constant, throbbing, and worse when sitting down with history of constipation in the past. Fluctuation is noted near the anal region. The Resident decides to drain the ischioanal abscess. Which of the following structures can be injured while draining the ischioanal abscess?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior rectal nerve

 

The ischioanal fossa is a fat-filled wedge-shaped space on either side of the anal canal. Infections in this region can lead to an ischioanal abscess, which requires surgical drainage.

 

  • The inferior rectal nerve (branch of the pudendal nerve) crosses the ischioanal fossa to supply the external anal sphincter and skin around the anus.
  • During surgical drainage of an ischioanal abscess, this nerve is at risk of injury, which may result in sensory loss around the anal margin and weakness of the external anal sphincter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pudendal nerve: Runs in the pudendal canal (Alcock’s canal) along the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa. It is deeper and protected, so less likely to be injured during routine drainage.

 

Option C. Internal pudendal artery: Accompanies the pudendal nerve in Alcock’s canal. Like the pudendal nerve, it is deeper and less likely to be injured directly during drainage.

 

Option D. Posterior labial nerve: A branch of the perineal nerve (from pudendal). Supplies skin of posterior part of labia. Not directly endangered during ischioanal abscess drainage.

A 36-year-old woman is referred for evaluation because of hematuria and haemoptysis since 2 weeks. DLCO is 120% of normal with normal lung volumes. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Microscopic polyangiitis

 

Microscopic polyangiitis is a small-vessel vasculitis causing rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis, presenting with hematuria and hemoptysis. Elevated DLCO suggests alveolar hemorrhage due to increased carbon monoxide uptake. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Pulmonary hypertension: Does not cause hematuria and usually lowers DLCO. 

 

Option B. Asthma: Causes airway obstruction, not hematuria or hemoptysis. 

 

Option C. Wegener’s granulomatosis: Also causes hematuria and hemoptysis but typically associated with granulomas and elevated c-ANCA, which differentiates it from microscopic polyangiitis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with sudden-onset palpitations and lightheadedness while playing video games. He states this has occurred intermittently over the past year, but the episodes typically resolve spontaneously after a few minutes. He denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope. ECG is shown below. Which of the following abnormalities is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ectopic atrial pacemaker activity

 

Given the clinical presentation of a 17-year-old with sudden-onset palpitations and lightheadedness, with intermittent episodes resolving spontaneously, this suggests a supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) of atrial origin.

 

The ECG likely shows a narrow complex tachycardia consistent with an atrial tachycardia arising from an ectopic atrial pacemaker.

 

Ectopic atrial pacemaker activity matches ectopic atrial tachycardia, causing palpitations from abnormal atrial impulses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Accessory pathway bypassing the AV node: Accessory pathway bypassing the AV node is typical of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, causing atrioventricular re-entrant tachycardia (AVRT), usually diagnosed with characteristic delta waves on ECG.

 

Option B. Degeneration of the atrioventricular conduction system: Degeneration of the AV conduction system causes heart block, uncommon in young patients and unlikely to cause SVT.

 

Option D. Dysfunction of the sinoatrial node: Dysfunction of the sinoatrial node results in bradycardia or pauses, not tachycardia.

questions.text: Select the one which doesn’t cause Urethritis in males:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Haemophilus ducreyi

 

  • Urethritis in males is commonly caused by sexually transmitted pathogens like Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, Trichomonas vaginalis, Mycoplasma genitalium, Ureaplasma urealyticum.
  • Haemophilus ducreyi, however, does not cause urethritis.
    • It is the causative agent of chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection characterized by:
      • Painful genital ulcers
      • Painful, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes)
    • It does not involve the urethra or cause urethral discharge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichomoniasis: 

 

  • Caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • Can cause nongonococcal urethritis in men → dysuria, mild discharge.

 

Option C. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars D–K) is a leading cause of nongonococcal urethritis.

 

Option D. Gonococcus: Neisseria gonorrhoeae → classic cause of purulent urethritis in men.

questions.solution:
Ans. A) McCoy Cell Line

 

  • Clinical case: male with urethritis, pus cells present in urine but no organisms seen on Gram stain.
  • This is a classic description of nongonococcal urethritis (NGU) caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • Chlamydia trachomatis is an obligate intracellular bacterium → cannot grow on routine artificial culture media.
  • Best culture method: growth in McCoy cell line (or other susceptible cell lines) followed by detection of inclusions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thayer-Martin Medium:

 

  • Chocolate agar with antibiotics (VCN = vancomycin, colistin, nystatin).
  • Selective for Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Would be useful if organisms were seen on Gram stain, but not for Chlamydia.

 

Option C. Lowenstein-Jensen (L.J.) medium:

 

  • Used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture.
  • Not for Chlamydia or urethritis pathogens.

 

Option D. Levinthal Medium:

 

  • Special medium used for Haemophilus influenzae, requiring X (hemin) and V (NAD) factors.
  • Not relevant in urethritis.

A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to severe right leg pain. Right-sided dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are absent, and the popliteal pulse is barely palpable. Emergency embolectomy is performed and a gelatinous mass causing arterial occlusion is successfully removed. Histopathologic section of the mass is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely origin of this patient's embolus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left atrium 

 

The image shows a myxoma, a benign gelatinous tumor frequent in the left atrium. Such a mass can embolize to peripheral arteries after detachment, causing acute arterial occlusion as described. Myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumors and are classically found in the left atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral vein: Emboli from the venous system (e.g., femoral vein) typically cause pulmonary embolism, not arterial occlusion in the leg.

 

Option B. Descending aorta: Atheroemboli from the aorta could cause arterial occlusion, but histology would show cholesterol clefts, not myxoid material.

 

Option D. Left ventricle: Emboli from the left ventricle are usually due to mural thrombi, seen after myocardial infarction, not gelatinous myxoma tissue.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying the variability in drug metabolism across individuals using isoniazid. Variation in which of the following metabolic processes is the most likely explanation for this observation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acetylation

 

The graph shows a bimodal distribution of plasma isoniazid (INH) concentrations among individuals, representing populations of slow and fast acetylators. Acetylation is mediated by the N-acetyltransferase enzyme, which exhibits genetic polymorphism leading to classification of individuals as slow or fast acetylators, directly explaining the bimodal plasma concentrations of isoniazid. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylation: Methylation is a phase II metabolic reaction that involves transferring a methyl group to substrates, often leading to detoxification or alteration of activity. While methylation occurs with many drugs, it is not the primary pathway responsible for the variability in isoniazid metabolism or plasma concentration differences seen in populations.

 

Option B. Hydrolysis: Hydrolysis involves cleavage of chemical bonds through the addition of water, commonly seen in ester or amide bonds. This reaction is important for activating or deactivating some drugs, but it is not a significant metabolic pathway for isoniazid, hence not contributing to its variable plasma levels.

 

Option D. Glucuronidation: Glucuronidation is a major phase II conjugation reaction that attaches glucuronic acid to lipophilic molecules to enhance excretion. It typically affects drugs like morphine or bilirubin but is not the key metabolic step for isoniazid nor responsible for its polymorphic metabolism.

questions.text:
Which of the following are features of severe dengue?

 

  1. AST and ALT are more than 1000 IU
  2. Hepatomegaly >1cm
  3. Leucopenia plus thrombocytopenia
  4. Severe bleeding 
  5. Vomiting
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4

 

  • Severe plasma leakage → leading to shock or respiratory distress
  • Severe bleeding → as evaluated clinically
  • Severe organ impairment → e.g., liver (AST/ALT >1000 IU/L), CNS involvement, heart or other organ failure

So:

  • (1) AST/ALT >1000 IU → severe organ involvement
  • (4) Severe bleeding → hallmark of severe dengue

questions.text: What is the normal volume of prostate gland?

True about cholera: 

 

  1. There’s no role of mass prophylaxis in cholera outbreak
  2. Dukoral vaccine can be given for age less than 2 years
  3. Dukoral vaccine is Monovalent
  4. Shanchol Vaccine is Bivalent 
  5. Gastric buffer is added in shanchol vaccine 
  6. 5% Cresol is used for disinfecting Feces, vomitus during outbreaks
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4, 6

 

1. There’s no role of mass prophylaxis in cholera outbreak → True.

 

  • WHO does not recommend mass chemoprophylaxis during outbreaks due to risk of resistance.
  • Focus is on case management, safe water, sanitation, and selective vaccination.

 

3. Dukoral vaccine is Monovalent → True.

 

  • Contains Vibrio cholerae O1 only → monovalent.

 

4. Shanchol vaccine is Bivalent → True.

 

  • Killed oral vaccine containing V. cholerae O1 and O139 → bivalent.

 

6. 5% Cresol is used for disinfecting feces, vomitus during outbreaks → True.

 

  • Standard disinfectant recommended during cholera outbreaks.

 

Other statement:

 

2. Dukoral vaccine can be given for age less than 2 years → False.

 

  • Dukoral (oral, killed whole-cell + recombinant B subunit vaccine) is licensed for ≥2 years only.
  • Not given below 2 years.

 

5. Gastric buffer is added in Shanchol vaccine → False.

 

  • Buffer is required for Dukoral (because of B subunit).
  • Shanchol does not require buffer.

questions.text: Match the following Subarachnoid Cisterns with their respective Vascular contents:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

The subarachnoid cisterns are enlargements of the subarachnoid space where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collects. Each cistern contains specific vascular structures.

 

A. Cisterna magna (cerebello-medullary cistern):

 

  • Located between the cerebellum and medulla.
  • Contains vertebral arteries and origin of posterior inferior cerebellar arteries (PICA).
  • Match → 2. Vertebral artery

 

B. Quadrigeminal cistern:

 

  • Located posterior to the colliculi and around the pineal gland.
  • Contains great cerebral vein (vein of Galen) and posterior cerebral arteries.
  • Match → 3. Vein of Galen

 

C. Sylvian cistern (lateral fissure cistern):

 

  • Located along the lateral sulcus between frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes.
  • Contains middle cerebral artery (MCA) and its branches.
  • Match → 4. MCA

 

D. Pontine cistern:

 

  • Located around the ventral surface of the pons.
  • Contains the basilar artery and origin of anterior inferior cerebellar arteries (AICA).
  • Match → 1. Basilar artery

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve?

 

  1. Abductor hallucis
  2. Flexor digitorum accessorius
  3. Flexor hallucis brevis
  4. First lumbrical
  5. First interossei
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 5

 

The tibial nerve divides into the medial plantar nerve and lateral plantar nerve after passing beneath the flexor retinaculum. Their distributions differ:

 

Medial plantar nerve supplies:

 

  • Abductor hallucis
  • Flexor hallucis brevis
  • Flexor digitorum brevis
  • First lumbrical

 

 

Lateral plantar nerve supplies:

 

  • Flexor digitorum accessorius (quadratus plantae)
  • Abductor digiti minimi
  • All interossei (dorsal and plantar)
  • Lumbricals 2–4
  • Adductor hallucis
  • Lateral head of flexor hallucis brevis

 

 

Checking the options:

 

  1. Abductor hallucis → medial plantar nerve (not lateral).
  2. Flexor digitorum accessorius → lateral plantar nerve.
  3. Flexor hallucis brevis → medial plantar (medial head) and lateral plantar (lateral head).
  4. First lumbrical → medial plantar nerve.
  5. First interossei → lateral plantar nerve

Farmer presents with the features of high fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, vomiting and diarrhea and hypotension. Which stain will help in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wayson’s stain

 

  • The farmer presents with high fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), vomiting, diarrhea, hypotension → classic features of plague (Yersinia pestis).
  • Diagnosis is supported by Wayson’s stain, which shows:
    • Safety-pin appearance of Yersinia pestis (bipolar staining with a clear central area).
  • This stain is therefore highly useful in rapid presumptive diagnosis of plague.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neisser stain: Used for demonstrating metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

 

Option C. Albert’s stain: Also used for Corynebacterium diphtheriae, highlighting metachromatic granules (green bacilli with blue/black granules).

 

 

Option D. McFadyean’s stain: Used in Bacillus anthracis to demonstrate the polypeptide capsule (appears as purple capsule on a blue bacillus background).

Fibres from the marked Structure pass through which Cerebellar peduncle originating at the level of?
Which of the following species of hemophilus requires only factor X for growth?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemophilus ducreyi

 

Haemophilus Growth Factors

 

  • Factor X = Hemin (heat-stable)
    • An iron-containing porphyrin.
    • Required for synthesis of cytochromes and enzymes involved in electron transport.
    • Found in blood (RBCs → hemoglobin breakdown).
  • Factor V = NAD / NADP (heat-labile)
    • Functions as a coenzyme in redox reactions.
    • Not synthesized by Haemophilus species.
    • Supplied by other bacteria (eg, Staphylococcus aureus → “satellite phenomenon”) or enriched media.

 

H. ducreyi → requires only factor X (causes chancroid).

 

H. influenzae → requires both X and V factors.

 

H. parainfluenzae → requires only factor V.

 

H. paraphrophilus → requires neither (can grow without X and V).

Advantages of Saline wet mount over iodine wet mount is/are?

 

  1. Demonstration of motility of trophozoites
  2. Identify the internal structures of the cyst
  3. Differentiate bile stained vs non bile stained eggs
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A & C

 

  • Saline wet mount:
    • Demonstrates motility of trophozoites (since iodine kills motility).
    • Differentiates bile-stained vs non-bile-stained eggs.
  • Iodine wet mount:
    • Kills trophozoites, hence no motility seen.
    • Better for identifying internal structures of cysts (iodine stains glycogen and nuclei).

 

Option B. Identifying the internal structures of the cyst is an advantage of IODINE mount not SALINE mount.

questions.text: The strategy adopted by mycobacterium tuberculosis to avoid intracellular killing is:
Which of the following is not a derivative of neural crest cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retinal pigment epithelium

 

Neural crest cells contribute extensively to structures in the eye as well as the rest of the body.

 

Neural crest derivatives in the eye:

 

  • Corneal stroma and endothelium
  • Sclera
  • Choroid
  • Ciliary muscles
  • Ciliary ganglion
  • Iris stroma
  • Ganglion cell layer of retina

 

Not derived from neural crest:

 

  • Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and neural retina → these arise from the neuroectoderm of the optic cup, not from neural crest.

What level of the vertebral column does the given cross- sectional image correspond to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T9

 

Supportive anatomical points for T9 section

 

1] Liver and Stomach relationship

 

  • Large portion of the right lobe of liver is seen.
  • On the left side, the stomach (fundus/body region) is visible with air density.
  • This corresponds to the mid-thoracic level, around T9.

 

2] Esophagus

 

  • Seen as a circular structure close to midline, posterior to the left atrium, about to pass through the diaphragm at the esophageal hiatus (T10).
  • Thus, T9 is just above the esophageal opening

 

3] Lungs

 

  • Still visible here (lower lobes).
  • At T9 level, lungs are tapering off before ending at the costodiaphragmatic recess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T12: By this level, lungs and esophagus would no longer be seen; only abdominal structures (aortic hiatus, celiac trunk) appear.

 

Option B. T10: The esophagus would be entering the diaphragm (hiatus), lungs almost ending. The lungs in this image are more prominent, which fits T9 better.

 

Option D. T11: Esophagus would not be visible (already passed through diaphragm), lungs almost absent.
